item.title: Basic C++
item.dc:creator: @person1936 person1936
item.description:
@person1936 wrote:

added pause to the file so that u can read it

#include<iostream>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
 
int main()
{
 
char uname[20];
cout << "Username: ";
cin >> uname;
 
char pass[20];
cout << "Password: ";
cin >> pass;
char zomg[4];
if (pass == zomg)
   cout << "\n Thank you for logging in! \n";
	system("pause");
else
   cout << "Invalid password, Please try again. \n";
	system("pause");
 
return 0;
}

item.title: Basic C++
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

i wrote my own strcmp function, evil_. if i used the standard one then, yes, you'd be correct.

actually, Evil_ is right, because you #include in your code, so it uses string.h’s strcmp() and not your own. in fact, main() doesn’t recognize your strcmp(), because if it did, you would get a compilation error. you would need to either place the implementation of your strcmp() or at least its declartion before main() in your code.

Rotfl, strcmp ftw. == operator is not overwridden, you all is fail.

and you can’t override operators for primitive types

Read full topic

item.description:

Rotfl, strcmp ftw. == operator is not overwridden, you all is fail.

Use stricmp, which means string ingore-case compare

item.title: Basic C++
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Don’t use char pointers unless you have a good reason. Use std::string.

C-strings, pointers, C-functions, C-Casts, all these are evil and should be avoided.

In short:
C++ > C

If there is a C++ way, use it.

Anyway, your code has indeed quite a few errors, and so does the code of quite a few people who have responded.

-strcmp() does indeed return 0 if the two strings match (And you should not use !, because it does not have a LOGICAL_NOT meaning)

-Your char buffers are only 4 characters long, and you do no checks at all, which means that they are extremelly likely to overflow, and lead to unexpected behaviour (most likely crashes).

-Someone who responded uses uninitialized char pointers as if they were buffers. That of course is wrong, as a char pointer is exactly that, a pointer to a char. NOT a char, NOT a char array.

-Note also that, that re-making a standard library function is not a good idea, especially if you change its actual behaviour. The real strcmp does a lexicographical compare. Also, if you really wanted to, you should do it right. strcmp() does not modify the char buffers it takes as parameters, so they should be const (char const *).

Read full topic

item.title: Basic C++
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

i wrote my own strcmp function, evil_. if i used the standard one then, yes, you’d be correct.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: December 03, 2007, 04:44:13 PM[/size][hr][quote=“sparkz, post:12, topic:161896”]die, i said strcmp first.

the reason you cant use == is because its a pointer to the beginning of the array, so they will not be ‘equal’ inless they point to the same memory location.

or you could just string.h ftw[/quote]
sparkz, correct, because in certain cases arrays are treated as pointers to the first element in the array; so myArray == &(myArray[0]) would be true but myArray == copyOfMyArrayWithAllOfItsElements is false;

Read full topic

item.title: Basic C++
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote="_cake, post:13, topic:161896"][code]#include

int main() {
std::cout << "Username: ";
char* username;
std::cin >> username;
std::cout << std::endl;
std::cout << "Password: ";
char* password;
std::cin >> password;
std::cout << std::endl;
if(strcmp(password, “zomg”))
std::cout << std::endl << “Thank you for logging in!” << std::endl;
else
std::cout << std::endl << “Invalid password.” << std::endl;
return 0;
}

int strcmp(char* str1, char* str2) {
for(unsigned i = 0; i < (sizeof str2) / (sizeof(char)); i++)
if(str1[i] != str2[i])
return 0;
return 1;
}[/code][/quote]
This won’t work, as when you put in the correct password it will say “Invalid Password” otherwise, it’ll say “Thank you for logging in”

if(strcmp(password, "zomg"))

The reason being, strcmp returns 0 if the two words are the same, and 0 is false so the correct statement would be:

if(!strcmp(password, "zomg"))

Read full topic

item.title: Basic C++
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

[code]#include

int custom_strcmp(const char [], const char []);

int main() {
std::cout << "Username: ";
char username[40];
std::cin >> username;
std::cout << std::endl;
std::cout << "Password: ";
char password[40];
std::cin >> password;
std::cout << std::endl;
if(custom_strcmp(password, “zomg”))
std::cout << std::endl << “Thank you for logging in!” << std::endl;
else
std::cout << std::endl << “Invalid password.” << std::endl;
return 0;
}

int custom_strcmp(const char[] str1, const char[] str2) {
for(unsigned i = 0; i < (sizeof str2) / (sizeof(char)); i++)
if(str[i] != NULL && str2[i] != NULL)
if(str1[i] != str2[i])
return 0;
return 1;
}[/code]

Read full topic

sparkz:

strcmp

[code]#include

using namespace std;

int main()
{

char uname[20];
cout << "Username: ";
cin >> uname;

char pass[10];
cout << "Password: ";
cin >> pass;
//char zomg[5] = “zomg”;

if (!strcmp(pass,“zomg”)) { // or uncomment above and remove quotes
cout << “\n Thank you for logging in! \n”;
cin.ignore();
cin.get();

}
else {
cout << “Invalid password, Please try again. \n”;
cin.ignore();
cin.get();
}

return 0;
}[/code]

item.title: Basic C++
item.dc:creator: @usernamelol .Fusion
item.description:
@usernamelol wrote:

[quote=“Baros Rocks, post:4, topic:161896”][code=cpp]#include
#include
using namespace std;

int main()
{

string uname;
cout << "Username: ";
cin >> uname;

string pass;
cout << "Password: ";
cin >> pass;
if (pass == “zomg”)
cout << “\n Thank you for logging in! \n”;
else
cout << “Invalid password, Please try again. \n”;
system(“pause”);
return 0;
}
[/code]
Not sure why it doesn’t work as a char array, but, it works as a string variable.[/quote]
Thanks, i thought it was something to do with that but I wasn’t sure.

And system(“pause”); is not needed, as shell does not support it.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic C++
item.dc:creator: @Baros_Rocks Baros Rocks
item.description:
@Baros_Rocks wrote:

[code=cpp]
#include
#include
using namespace std;

int main()
{

char uname[20];
cout << "Username: ";
cin >> uname;

char pass[20];
cout << "Password: ";
cin >> pass;
char zomg[4];
if (pass == zomg)
cout << “\n Thank you for logging in! \n”;
else
cout << “Invalid password, Please try again. \n”;

return 0;
}[/code]

You put >= instead of ==.

Rather then making a whole new variable, you could of used:

if (pass == “zomg”){
…
}

[code=cpp]

#include
using namespace std;

{
